commander.name: Luigi Bianchi
commander.career_notes: Born 1908, Spanish Civil War veteran (4x Silver Medal of Military Valor), commanded 155° Gruppo from formation through December 1941 deployment to North Africa. Decorated with German Iron Cross 1st and 2nd Class. Returned to Italy December 1941, appointed assistant air attaché Madrid January 1942. Postwar: NATO and Italian Air Force senior leadership roles.

subordinate_squadriglie.notes: Joined 155° Gruppo mid-April 1941 from 20° Gruppo. Operated from Ain el Gazala April-December 1941.

subordinate_squadriglie.notable_personnel: Capitano Carlo Miani (later flew MC.202 with unit in 1942)
subordinate_squadriglie.notes: Original squadriglia from gruppo formation January 1941.

subordinate_squadriglie.notable_personnel: Sergente Maggiore Aldo Buvoli (4 victories 9 July 1941, Silver Medal)
subordinate_squadriglie.notes: Original squadriglia. Notable engagement 9 July 1941 Tripoli harbor defense.

specifications.variant_notes: G.50bis 'improved' model with increased fuel capacity, modified fuselage, new rudder, pilot armor. A.S. (Africa Sahariana) version with sand filters. Desert sand reduced engine lifespan to 70-80 hours despite filters.

ordnance.ammunition_notes: 37 aircraft x 600 rounds (2x 12.7mm guns, 300 rpg) = 22,200 rounds loaded. Estimated 2x combat loads in reserve = 44,400 total.
ordnance.fuel_notes: G.50bis increased fuel capacity ~1027L per aircraft. 37 aircraft x 1027L ≈ 38,000L

ground_support_vehicles.notes: Fighter gruppo required fewer support vehicles than bomber units. Primarily fuel, spare parts, and personnel transport.

supply.supply_notes: Operational through October-November. Heavy aircraft losses (18 G.50s destroyed 19 Nov Sidi Rezegh raid, 5 more 22 Dec Agedabia) reduced operational capability. Unit withdrew to Italy end December 1941 with 'virtually no aircraft left'.

operations_history.enemy: Blenheim IV bombers (110 Squadron RAF from Malta)
operations_history.notes: Buvoli intercepted 7 Blenheims attacking Tripoli harbor. Shot down 2 confirmed (1 over port, 1 over sea), 2 more failed to return to Malta. Awarded Silver Medal of Military Valor. Two CR.42s from 151° Gruppo also engaged.
Routine combat air patrols supporting siege of Tobruk and protecting Axis supply convoys. Engaged RAF fighters and bombers from Desert Air Force.
British Desert Air Force attacked Ain el Gazala airfields on Crusader opening day. 13 aircraft destroyed on ground (10 G.50s confirmed), significant blow to 155° Gruppo operational strength.

Commando raid on airfields. 155° Gruppo lost 18 G.50s (mix of ground destruction and combat losses). Unit operational capability severely degraded. Note: 20° Gruppo at Sidi Rezegh simultaneously lost 16 of 19 G.50s, 80 personnel captured.
Continued operations with drastically reduced aircraft strength. Provided air cover for Axis withdrawal from Cyrenaica.
5 additional G.50s lost at Agedabia (likely ground attack or abandoned during withdrawal). With 'virtually no aircraft left', 155° Gruppo ordered to return to Italy.

155° Gruppo returned to Italy end December 1941 after losing 43+ aircraft (18+13+5+combat attrition). Unit absorbed into reconstituted 51° Stormo (disbanded Sept 1940, reformed 1 Jan 1942). Re-equipped with Macchi C.202 March 1942, redeployed Sicily June 1942 for Malta operations.

combat_summary_1941q4.notes: Catastrophic quarter for 155° Gruppo. Entered October with ~37 operational G.50bis. Lost 46 aircraft (36 ground, 10 combat) representing 124% of initial strength. Ground attacks 18-19 November destroyed unit combat effectiveness. Withdrew to Italy with surviving personnel, virtually no aircraft. Demonstrated vulnerability of forward desert airfields to ground attacks and sustained air operations.

notable_actions.significance: Sergente Maggiore Aldo Buvoli (378ª Squadriglia) single-handedly engaged 7 RAF Blenheims, claimed 4 victories (2 confirmed destroyed, 2 missing). Awarded Silver Medal of Military Valor. Demonstrated G.50bis effectiveness against medium bombers in skilled hands despite inadequate armament (2x 12.7mm).

notable_actions.action: Ain el Gazala / Sidi Rezegh Catastrophe
notable_actions.significance: 155° Gruppo lost 31 G.50s in 48 hours (13 on 18th, 18 on 19th) to Desert Air Force ground attacks and commando raids. Worst two-day loss period for unit in North Africa. Exposed critical vulnerability of Axis forward airfields to British ground-air coordination. Unit never recovered operational strength in theater.

metadata.notes: 155° Gruppo Autonomo Caccia Terrestre was formed 15 January 1941 under Maggiore Luigi Bianchi with three squadriglie (351ª, 360ª, 378ª) equipped with 37 Fiat G.50bis fighters. Unit arrived Libya 31 January 1941. 351ª Squadriglia transferred from 20° Gruppo in mid-April. Operated from Ain el Gazala April-December 1941. Notable engagement: Sergente Maggiore Aldo Buvoli (378ª) claimed 4 Blenheims 9 July 1941 Tripoli defense (Silver Medal). Operation Crusader disaster: Lost 31 aircraft 18-19 November (13 ground attack 18th, 18 Sidi Rezegh raid 19th), 5 more at Agedabia 22 December, plus combat attrition. 8 KIA. Withdrew to Italy end December with 'virtually no aircraft left'. Reformed as part of 51° Stormo January 1942, re-equipped MC.202 March 1942, deployed Sicily June 1942. Tier 1/2 sources confirm: commander (Luigi Bianchi verified Italian Wikipedia), unit designation (Asisbiz), aircraft variant (G.50bis verified multiple sources), operational dates/locations (Asisbiz, forum sources), major battles (Crusader losses widely documented).
